articles.personality_title: Celebrating scientists who are making labs kinder and fairer
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A new podcast series is shining a light on scientists who work hard to make science a friendlier and more equal place for everyone.

**What happened**
Eight inspiring researchers, featured in Nature’s Changemaker series, will share their stories in this upcoming podcast introduced by Kendall Powell and Deborah Daley.

**Impact**
Their efforts are helping to create a scientific community that welcomes diversity and supports all its members, making labs more inclusive and positive.

**What's next**
Listeners can look forward to hearing these changemakers share their experiences and ideas, inspiring more people to build a fairer future in science.

**One-sentence takeaway**
These scientists are leading the way to a kinder, more inclusive world in science, one story at a time.

articles.title: UN Rights Council Rejects Bad-Faith Bid to End Eritrea Scrutiny
articles.content:
Click to expand Image A session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, Geneva, Switzerland, February 26, 2024. © 2024 Hannes P Albert/picture-alliance/dpa/AP Photo

Today the UN Human Rights Council firmly rejected Eritrea’s attempt to end scrutiny of its human rights situation. Council members decisively voted down the Eritrean government’s resolution to end the mandate of the UN special rapporteur on the situation of human rights in Eritrea and instead renewed the mandate for another year.

This vote – with 25 states voting against the resolution and only 4 in favor – sends an important message that the international community is not fooled by Eritrea’s efforts to distract from, and discredit, independent human rights reporting on the country’s dire rights record.

The resolution Eritrea presented claimed that “gaps in the promotion and protection of human rights in Eritrea are not systemic,” and “like other developing countries,” Eritrea simply faces “capacity constraints” when it comes to human rights protection.

The special rapporteur’s reporting, which shines a much-needed spotlight on a devastating reality, begs to differ.

Presenting his latest report to the Council in June, the special rapporteur highlighted the lack of progress on accountability ten years after the publication of the landmark report of the UN Commission of Inquiry on Eritrea, which concluded that “systematic, widespread and gross human rights violations […] committed in Eritrea under the authority of the Government […] may constitute crimes against humanity.”

The special rapporteur’s report noted that arbitrary detentions and enforced disappearances remained widespread and systematic, and that freedom of religion remains severely restricted, among other serious abuses. It also voiced grave concerns over the continued abusive policy of indefinite national service, including compulsory military conscription, which means that most Eritreans spend their lives in government service.

During negotiations, Eritrea argued that the mandate should end because it had no impact, and because the special rapporteur had never set foot in the country: a circular argument suggesting their refusal to cooperate should be grounds to end international scrutiny.

Following the defeat of their initiative, Eritrea once again attacked the mandate and vowed to “never engage” with the special rapporteur, underscoring again that this lack of cooperation is the very reason such scrutiny remains essential.

The Council’s firm rejection of Eritrea’s initiative comes as a relief to Eritrean rights groups who had been campaigning for the renewal since May.

Their message is clear: only once Eritrea ends its abusive practice of indefinite conscription, releases all those being held unlawfully, and Eritreans are free to speak, meet, and pray freely, should the Council even consider changing tack.
articles.reasoning: The article reports that the UN Human Rights Council has decisively rejected Eritrea's attempt to end international scrutiny of its human rights abuses, renewing the mandate of the special rapporteur. This shows international commitment to accountability and human rights protection, which is a positive and hopeful development despite the ongoing challenges.
articles.personality_title: UN stands strong for Eritrea's human rights with renewed scrutiny
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The United Nations Human Rights Council has been monitoring the human rights situation in Eritrea for years, highlighting serious concerns like forced military service and restricted freedoms.

**What happened**
Recently, Eritrea tried to stop this monitoring by asking the Council to end the special rapporteur’s mandate, but the Council voted overwhelmingly to keep it for another year.

**Impact**
This decision shows the world is not ignoring Eritrea’s human rights issues and supports ongoing efforts to hold the government accountable and protect Eritreans’ freedoms.

**What's next**
Eritrean rights groups are hopeful and will continue pushing for real changes—like ending indefinite military service and freeing those detained unlawfully—while the UN keeps watching closely.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The UN’s firm stand sends a hopeful message that justice and human rights in Eritrea will not be overlooked.

articles.title: Pride in London returns as events struggle with falling funds
articles.content: UK Pride organisers tell the BBC that less sponsorship funding and fewer volunteers are behind cancelled events.
articles.reasoning: Despite challenges with funding and volunteer shortages causing some event cancellations, the return of Pride in London represents a positive cultural celebration and a sign of community resilience and unity in support of LGBTQ+ rights.
articles.personality_title: Pride in London shines bright despite challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Pride events across the UK have faced tough times with less money and fewer helpers. This has caused some celebrations to be canceled.

**What happened**
Despite these hurdles, Pride in London made a strong comeback this year, showing the city’s spirit and love.

**Impact**
The return brought people together, reminding everyone of the power of community and the ongoing support for LGBTQ+ rights.

**What's next**
Organizers hope to rebuild sponsorships and invite more volunteers to keep the spirit alive for future celebrations.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Even when times get tough, Pride in London proves that love and unity can light the way forward.
